title: Mixed Methyl Aryloxy Rare-Earth-Metal Complexes Stabilized by a Superbulky Tris(pyrazolyl)borato Ligand

reactions.text: We have shown previously that scorpionate-supported rare-earth-metal methyl complexes TptBu,MeLuMe2 and TptBu,MeLn(AlMe4)Me give access to mixed methyl alkyl Ln(III) complexes TptBu,MeLuRMe (R = CH2SiMe3, CH2Ph). Therefore, it was reasoned that the role of these versatile precursors might be expanded to selective protonolyses with phenols as well as salt metatheses with potassium phenolates, respectively. We set out to treat TptBu,MeLuMe2, supposedly the most reactive because sterically least hindered, with various alkyl-substituted phenol derivatives HOAr (HOC6H3Me2-2,6, HOC6H3iPr2-2,6, HOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5, HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4) (Scheme 1). The reaction of TptBu,MeLuMe2 with an equimolar amount of the least bulky HOC6H3Me2-2,6 in n-hexane at ambient temperature was indicated by an instant methane evolution. After evaporation of the solvent, crystallization from n-hexane afforded colorless crystals identified as bis(aryloxy) derivatives TptBu,MeLu(OC6H3Me2-2,6)2 (1-Lu) and reactant TptBu,MeLuMe2 via 1H NMR spectroscopy. The formation of 1-Lu (via ligand redistribution or double protonolysis) could not be prevented by performing the reaction at lower temperature (−40 °C). The same behavior was found when carrying out the reaction in toluene. In order to obtain the bis(aryloxy) lutetium complex more efficiently, the reaction was carried out with 2 equiv of the respective phenol. Similarly, protonolysis of TptBu,MeLuMe2 with 1 equiv HOC6H3iPr2-2,6 in n-hexane led to the bis(aryloxy) derivative TptBu,MeLu(OC6H3iPr2-2,6)2 (2-Lu), even though the sterics of the respective phenol were markedly increased. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra of 1-Lu and 2-Lu at ambient temperatures showed only one set of signals for the pyrazolyl groups of the TptBu,Me ligand, similar to that of the starting compound.

The treatment of TptBu,MeLuMe2 with 2 equiv of the increasingly electron deficient phenol HOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 under reaction conditions chosen as for 1-Lu and 2-Lu led to rapid decomposition of the dimethyl complex and a complicated reaction mixture. Therefore, a precooled solution of the reactant TptBu,MeLuMe2 in toluene was prepared and the respective phenol was added. Crystallization of the residue from toluene gave the bis(aryloxy) derivative TptBu,MeLu[OC6H3(CF3)2-3,5]2 (3-Lu) in good yield. The 1H NMR spectrum of 3-Lu showed the pyrazolyl signals slightly shifted to higher fields compared to the starting material.

The treatment of TptBu,MeLuMe2 with 2 equiv of the increasingly electron deficient phenol HOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 under reaction conditions chosen as for 1-Lu and 2-Lu led to rapid decomposition of the dimethyl complex and a complicated reaction mixture. Therefore, a precooled solution of the reactant TptBu,MeLuMe2 in toluene was prepared and the respective phenol was added. Crystallization of the residue from toluene gave the bis(aryloxy) derivative TptBu,MeLu[OC6H3(CF3)2-3,5]2 (3-Lu) in good yield. The 1H NMR spectrum of 3-Lu showed the pyrazolyl signals slightly shifted to higher fields compared to the starting material.

As for the aforementioned syntheses, instant methane evolution, when treating a suspension of TptBu,MeLuMe2 in n-hexane with the tBu-substituted phenol, indicated a successful protonolysis reaction. The formation of complex TptBu,MeLuMe(OC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4) (4-Lu) could be confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy.

As for the aforementioned syntheses, instant methane evolution, when treating a suspension of TptBu,MeLuMe2 in n-hexane with the tBu-substituted phenol, indicated a successful protonolysis reaction. The formation of complex TptBu,MeLuMe(OC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4) (4-Lu) could be confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy.

Initial synthesis attempts with the sterically “most favored” pair TptBu,MeYMe(AlMe4)/KOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 toward putative TptBu,MeYMe(OC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4) (4-Y), however, failed in different solvents. To our great surprise, protonolysis of TptBu,MeYMe(AlMe4) with the respective phenolic proligand instead succeeded under mild reaction conditions (2 h at −35 °C; rapid decomposition of the yttrium complex in solution at ambient temperature) to yield 4-Y (Scheme 1). Other protonolysis attempts at mixed methyl/aryloxy Ln(III) complexes employing TptBu,MeLnMe(AlMe4) (Ln = Y, Lu) and less bulky HOAr led to complicated mixtures of products and no clean conversion. Single-crystalline 4-Y was obtained in good yields from a saturated solution in toluene.

Combining a solution of the rare-earth-metal precursor in toluene and a suspension of the potassium aryloxide in toluene and stirring the mixture for 6 h gave complexes TptBu,MeLnMe(OC6H3Me2-2,6) (5-Ln; Ln = Y, Lu) or TptBu,MeLnMe(OC6H3iPr2-2,6) (6-Ln; Ln = Y, Lu) along with insoluble K(AlMe4). Upon separation of the latter via filtration, crystals of 5-Ln and 6-Ln could be grown from saturated solutions of toluene in moderate to good yields.

Combining a solution of the rare-earth-metal precursor in toluene and a suspension of the potassium aryloxide in toluene and stirring the mixture for 6 h gave complexes TptBu,MeLnMe(OC6H3Me2-2,6) (5-Ln; Ln = Y, Lu) or TptBu,MeLnMe(OC6H3iPr2-2,6) (6-Ln; Ln = Y, Lu) along with insoluble K(AlMe4). Upon separation of the latter via filtration, crystals of 5-Ln and 6-Ln could be grown from saturated solutions of toluene in moderate to good yields.

The salt-metathesis protocol was also applicable for the pairs TptBu,MeLnMe(AlMe4)/KOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 (Ln = Y, Lu), subject to certain restrictions. While the synthesis of the lutetium complex TptBu,MeLnMe[OC6H3(CF3)2-3,5] (7-Lu) succeeded in toluene under the reaction conditions previously applied for 5-Ln and 6-Ln (Scheme 1), 1H NMR reaction studies revealed decomposition of the TptBu,Me ligand for yttrium. Subsequently, milder reaction conditions (4 h at −35 °C) were chosen for the effective synthesis of 7-Y. The 1H NMR spectra of 7-Lu and 7-Y show similar shifts of the Ln–C(Me) moiety at δ = 0.37 and 0.27 ppm (doublet with 2J(YH) = 1.8 Hz). Compared to other Me/OAr congeners a shift to higher fields was observed, which is in accordance with the electron-withdrawing CF3 groups of the aryloxy ligand. 19F NMR spectroscopy clearly identified both complexes at δ = −62.6 ppm (7-Y and 7-Lu), but unfortunately the expected quartet for the C–F coupling was hardly visible in the 13C{1H} NMR spectrum (7-Y: 132.3 ppm; 7-Lu: 132.1 ppm) and could also not be detected with longer measurement times due to decomposition of the complexes in solution, especially for 7-Y. Despite this, Ln–C(Me) carbon resonances were found at δ = 22.3 ppm as a doublet for yttrium (1J(YC) = 50.8 Hz) and as a singlet for lutetium at δ = 32.2 ppm. The 1H–89Y HSQC NMR spectrum shows a cross peak at δ =

Lu, Y) provide access for various bis(aryloxy) and mixed methyl aryloxy rare-earth-metal complexes. Applying protonolysis protocols with phenolic proligands HOAr, only the sterically most demanding derivative HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 efficiently afforded the desired complexes TptBu,MeLnMe(OAr).

Examination of the pairs TptBu,MeLnMe(AlMe4)/HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 in the presence of the strong neutral donor dmap led to the ion-separated complex [TptBu,MeLnMe(dmap)2][Me3Al(OC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4)] featuring an anionic heteroaluminato moiety. The proneness of the [TptBu,Me] ancillary ligand for C–H-bond activation in the presence of highly reactive Ln–Me moieties was further revealed by the isolation of complex [(Tp(tBu‑H)/(tBu)2,Me)Lu(OC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4).

HOC6H3Me2-2,6, HOC6H3iPr2-2,6, and HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and HOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 and dmap from ABCR and sublimed prior to use. Reagents KOC6H3iPr2-2,6, KOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4, and KOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 were prepared from the respective dry phenol and KH in tetrahydrofuran at ambient temperature, and were dried in vacuo prior to use.

HOC6H3Me2-2,6, HOC6H3iPr2-2,6, and HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and HOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 and dmap from ABCR and sublimed prior to use. Reagents KOC6H3iPr2-2,6, KOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4, and KOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 were prepared from the respective dry phenol and KH in tetrahydrofuran at ambient temperature, and were dried in vacuo prior to use.

A solution of HOC6H2Me2-2,6 (19.3 mg, 0.158 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) was added to a suspension of TptBu,MeLuMe2(50.0 mg, 0.080 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) and stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 1-Lu (62.0 mg, 0.074 mmol, 94%) as colorless crystals.

A solution of HOC6H2iPr2-2,6 (28.1 mg, 0.158 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) was added to a suspension of TptBu,MeLuMe2 (50.0 mg, 0.080 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) and stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 2-Lu (60.0 mg, 0.063 mmol, 80%) as colorless crystals.

A precooled solution of HOC6H2(CF3)2-3,5 (36.3 mg, 0.158 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a precooled solution of TptBu,MeLuMe2 (50.0 mg, 0.080 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) and stirred for 2 h at −35 °C. The reaction mixture was filtered and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 3-Lu (21.0 mg, 0.020 mmol, 37%) as colorless crystals.

A precooled solution of HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 (18.0 mg, 0.082 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) was added to a precooled suspension of TptBu,MeYMe(AlMe4) (50.0 mg, 0.081 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) at −35 °C. The suspension was stirred for 2 h at −35 °C. The reaction mixture was evaporated to dryness in vacuo and washed with n-hexane (3 × 2 mL). Crystallization from toluene yielded compound 4-Y (47 mg, 0.063 mmol, 78%).

A solution of HOC6H2tBu2-2,6-Me-4 (35.0 mg, 0.159 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) was added to a suspension of TptBu,MeLuMe2(100 mg, 0.158 mmol) in n-hexane (5 mL) and stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The solution was filtered and concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 4-Lu (100 mg, 0.121 mmol, 77%) as colorless crystals.

A suspension of KOC6H3Me2-2,6 (26.1 mg, 0.163 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of TptBu,MeYMe(AlMe4) (100 mg, 0.163 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The precipitate was removed by filtration and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 5-Y (62.0 mg, 0.096 mmol, 59%) as colorless crystals.

A suspension of KOC6H3Me2-2,6 (23.0 mg, 0.144 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of TptBu,MeLuMe(AlMe4) (100 mg, 0.143 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The precipitate was removed by filtration and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 5-Lu (51.0 mg, 0.069 mmol, 48%) as colorless crystals.

A suspension of KOC6H3iPr2-2,6 (35.3 mg, 0.163 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of TptBu,MeYMe(AlMe4) (100 mg, 0.163 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The precipitate was removed by filtration and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 6-Y (64.0 mg, 0.091 mmol, 56%) as colorless crystals.

A suspension of KOC6H3iPr2-2,6 (31.1 mg, 0.144 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of TptBu,MeLuMe(AlMe4) (100 mg, 0.143 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The precipitate was removed by filtration and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 6-Lu (80.0 mg, 0.101 mmol, 71%) as colorless crystals.

A suspension of KOC6H3(CF3)2-3,5 (38.2 mg, 0.142 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of TptBu,MeLuMe(AlMe4)](100 mg, 0.142 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at ambient temperature. The precipitate was removed by filtration and the solution was concentrated in vacuo. Crystallization at −35 °C yielded compound 7-Lu (80.0 mg, 0.095 mmol, 67%) as colorless crystals.

A solution of HOC6H3tBu2-2,6-Me-4) (15.7 mg, 0.071 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of TptBu,MeLuMe(AlMe4) (50.0 mg, 0.071 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). A solution of dmap (26.1 mg, 0.214 mmol) in n-hexane (1 mL) was added to the solution and the reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at ambient temperature. The precipitate was allowed to settle and washed with cold toluene (3 × 2 mL). The solid was dried in vacuo and gave 8-Lu as white solid (25.0 mg, 0.022 mmol, 31%). Crystals could be obtained by performing the reaction under the same conditions without stirring.
